VPR.A: The heatmap shows a {radial gradient} pattern.

EVJ.A: The global maximum heat value is {0.92}.

SC.A: The average heat value for Waste Management on the x-axis is {0.39}.

SC.Q: What is the average heat value for label Policy on the y-axis?

SC.Q: What is the average heat value for label Reliability on the y-axis?

NC.Q: Which has the higher heat value: the cell corresponding to Renewables and Consumption or the cell corresponding to Gas and Technology?
NC.A: The cell corresponding to {Gas} and {Technology} has a higher heat value.

NC.Q: Which has the higher heat value: the cell corresponding to Exploration and Consumption or the cell corresponding to Waste Management and Technology?
NC.A: The cell corresponding to {Exploration} and {Consumption} has a higher heat value.

NC.Q: Which has the higher heat value: the cell corresponding to Waste Management and Prices or the cell corresponding to Transmission and Reliability?
NC.A: The cell corresponding to {Transmission} and {Reliability} has a higher heat value.

NC.Q: Which has the higher heat value: the cell corresponding to Renewables and Policy or the cell corresponding to Exploration and Technology?
NC.A: The cell corresponding to {Exploration} and {Technology} has a higher heat value.

MSR.Q: In the heatmap, what are the row and column labels for all cells whose heat values fall within the range of 0.38 to 0.59?
MSR.A: The cells are: {(Gas, Consumption), (Nuclear, Consumption), (Renewables, Consumption), (Renewables, Infrastructure), (Transmission, Infrastructure), (Renewables, Investment), (Transmission, Investment), (Transmission, Policy), (Waste Management, Policy), (Transmission, Prices), (Waste Management, Prices), (Transmission, Production), (Waste Management, Production), (Waste Management, Reliability), (Transmission, Technology), (Waste Management, Technology)}.
